lead_paragraph: The decision, by judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, was the body’s first prosecution of the destruction of cultural heritage as a war crime.

byline.contributor: Sewell Chan contributed reporting from London.

headline.print_headline: Smashing of Shrines Punished as War Crime
headline.main: Prison Sentence Over Smashing of Shrines in Timbuktu: 9 Years

snippet: The decision, by judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, was the body’s first prosecution of the destruction of cultural heritage as a war crime....
abstract: International Criminal Court judges sentence Faqi al-Madhi, member of Al Qaeda-affiliated group Ansar Dine, to nine years for role in 2012 demolition of historic Muslim shrines in Timbuktu, Mali; ruling marks court's first prosecution of destruction of cultural heritage as war crime.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
